p: The other side of the coin of the fragrant substances is their allelopathic nature. Every chemical substance in the natural environment has more or fewer allelopathic properties, which, according to the definition of allelopathy, are substances produced by all living components of biocenosis (donors) interacting with each other (acceptors) with a multitude of chemical links. The active fragrant substances can be distributed primarily by plants [ 95], but also by microorganisms (like acetoin which is commonly associated with the smell of yogurt and produced through PGPR-Plant Growth Promoting Rhizobacteria [ 96], or others [ 97, 98]. Liu and Zhang [ 99] provide an interesting review on the effects of bacterial volatile emissions.
